text: what's up outliers today I'm going to show you exactly how I analyze the stock market to come up with a disposition so this informs everything that I do to make sure that the individual positions I'm putting on make sense relative to what I think is going on in the big picture so we're going to walk through three different levels that I like to look at and then I'm going to give you specific tools that you can use to analyze the specific data points that I like to look at so what's up everyone Eric here welcome back to the outliers let's get right in so the first thing we're going to start with is kind of this approach to analyzing the stock market you see that there's there's three levels at the very top level I need to understand a little bit about the economy whether I'm trading really really short time frames or much longer time frames I still want to know what's going on now to be clear for shorter term time frames I kind of care less about the much larger picture but my trading typically spans multiple time frames so I'm going to start with the economy then I'm going to rotate over to the stock market this is where I'm looking at things at a bit of a higher level and then I'll get down into individual stocks so let's start with what this process looks like how do we start

text: to start with the economy then I'm going to rotate over to the stock market this is where I'm looking at things at a bit of a higher level and then I'll get down into individual stocks so let's start with what this process looks like how do we start with the economy well I'm going to look at General production and productive indicators both for the economy RIT large but for then individual contributors us as consumers and as producers so I'm going to look at things like GDP which kind of summarizes a lot of that for US inflation metrics like CPI and PPI I'm going to look at unemployment fomc stances on things fomc right now is a lot more topical than it is sometimes it's not always in Vogue and not all of these things matter the same over different periods of time but I'm kind of starting zoomed out and then clicking in because knowing if we're in expanding or Contracting economy that's really important understanding the direction of inflation so on and so forth so I'm zooming you down into different metrics that kind of matter but in descending order almost so then after we get through kind of the broader government stuff I want to start looking at production so things like manufacturing and then also consumers how are the consumers doing because they're going to consume what's been manufactured they're going to be massive participants in things like the housing market so

text: we get through kind of the broader government stuff I want to start looking at production so things like manufacturing and then also consumers how are the consumers doing because they're going to consume what's been manufactured they're going to be massive participants in things like the housing market so this is how I visualize the broad Market by starting with the economy so how can we see all these different things well there's a few tools at your disposal and most of them are free so the first one I'll show you is from Fred and this is a really great website that you can set up your own dashboards that look at the specific metrics you're interested in so here I'm looking at the federal funds rate here I'm looking at the consumers so I'm looking at the linqu rate on credit cards I want to see single family Residential Mortgage charge offs or delinquency rates then I can look at charge offs based on businesses because people aren't paying their bills I can look at personal savings consumption literally whatever you want is in here I look at Broad sales as you could tell I look at things like GDP unemployment all of those metrics matter to me you literally can build your own dashboard right here in Fr it's completely free so that's the first resource I would put in front of you for economic data the other resource is also very cool within thinker swim
